Dialogue.Student: Hi, I'm Amina El-Sayed. It's nice to meet you.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Amina! It's great to meet you too. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m feeling a bit anxious, to be honest. The semester just started, and I’m already struggling.
Dialogue.Counselor: I understand. Starting a new semester can be overwhelming. Can you tell me more about what’s been bothering you?
Dialogue.Student: Well, I had a rough experience in a group project recently. I found it hard to present my ideas, and I felt embarrassed afterward.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds really tough. It’s completely normal to feel anxious about public speaking. How has this incident affected you?
Dialogue.Student: I’ve become more self-conscious in class discussions. I worry about participating now.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s understandable to feel that way after a difficult experience. Have you noticed if this affects your overall participation in your classes?
Dialogue.Student: Yes, I've been retreating more and avoiding group activities. I feel overshadowed by my classmates.
Dialogue.Counselor: That isolation can make things harder. What do you think might help you feel more comfortable participating again?
Dialogue.Student: I guess I just need to build some confidence back, but I'm not sure how to start.
Dialogue.Counselor: One approach could be to practice speaking in smaller, less intimidating settings before engaging in larger discussions. Would that be something you’d consider?
Dialogue.Student: Yes, that sounds less intimidating. I might try discussing topics with friends first.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a great idea! Also, remember that everyone has their own journey with public speaking. You're not alone in this.
Dialogue.Student: Thank you, I appreciate your understanding. It’s comforting to know I’m not the only one who struggles.
Dialogue.Counselor: Absolutely! Let’s follow up on this next week and see how things are going. How does that sound?
Dialogue.Student: That sounds good! Thank you for your help today.
Hi, I’m back. This week has been pretty challenging.
Dialogue.Counselor: Welcome back, Amina! What’s been going on this week?
Dialogue.Student: I attended a mid-term exam prep session with my classmates, but I couldn’t bring myself to speak up. I felt really overshadowed.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m sorry to hear that. It can be difficult when you feel lesser in a group. How did that experience impact you?
Dialogue.Student: It made me feel even more insecure about my ideas. I ended up saying nothing at all.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds tough. Have you thought about why you might be feeling so inhibited in that setting?
Dialogue.Student: I’m not sure, but I just feel inadequate compared to how easily others communicate.
Dialogue.Counselor: That's understandable. A lot of people feel comparison can be discouraging. Maybe instead of comparing, you can focus on what you can contribute.
Dialogue.Student: That makes sense, but it’s hard when everyone else seems so confident.
Dialogue.Counselor: Absolutely, that’s a common feeling. Would it help to set a small goal for your next group session, like sharing at least one thought?
Dialogue.Student: Yes, I think that could help. Having a goal might make me feel more committed to speaking up.
Dialogue.Counselor: Great! Setting a clear and achievable goal can pave the way for more involvement. Let me know how that goes next time we meet.
Dialogue.Student: I will! Thanks for encouraging me.
Hi, I’m back again. I’m still feeling pretty anxious.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Amina! I’m glad you’re here. What’s been happening this week?
Dialogue.Student: I missed a couple of opportunities to participate in class because of my fear of judgment. It’s like my anxiety is just growing.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds really difficult. Feeling stuck like that can be frustrating. What do you think is holding you back the most?
Dialogue.Student: I think it’s just my self-doubt. I feel isolated when I see others easily share their thoughts.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s tough to feel isolated among peers. Have you considered reaching out to a classmate or friend for support?
Dialogue.Student: I haven't tried that yet. I think I’m afraid they’ll judge me or think I’m weak.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s completely normal to feel that way, but remember that sharing your feelings might actually strengthen your connections with others.
Dialogue.Student: That’s a good point! I’ll think about reaching out.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s great! Also, don't forget that everyone has insecurities, even those who seem confident.
Dialogue.Student: I appreciate you reminding me of that. Sometimes I forget I’m not alone in this.
Dialogue.Counselor: Absolutely, Amina! You're not alone. We can work through these feelings together. Let’s check in next week and see how things are progressing.

Dialogue.Student: Hi, I'm back again. I went to counseling last week.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Amina! I’m glad you came back. How did the session go?
Dialogue.Student: It was a bit relieving to talk about my feelings, but I still feel uncertain about how to improve.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s completely understandable. What specific worries are you facing right now?
Dialogue.Student: I still feel unqualified in class and worry I won’t make it through my degree.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s normal to feel that way, especially in an academic environment. Have you thought of taking small steps towards improving your confidence?
Dialogue.Student: I want to, but I’m just not sure where to start.
Dialogue.Counselor: How about starting with setting a goal of speaking up in class just once a week? That’s manageable, right?
Dialogue.Student: Yes, that seems doable! I think that would help me improve over time.
Dialogue.Counselor: Absolutely! Remember, each small step you take is progress. It might feel uncomfortable initially, but you can do it!
Dialogue.Student: Thank you for the encouragement. It helps to have a plan.
Dialogue.Counselor: You're welcome, Amina! Let’s check in next time to celebrate your progress. You’ve got this!
